title: I want to play the clarinet but I prefer the sound when it is played in a higher pitch, almost a saxophone sound. Is there an effective technique to make the clarinet sound like this? - Quora

response.answer_text: First, do you mean “pitch” or “timbre”? If you mean that you prefer the clarinet's higher register, where it plays notes in the same range as the soprano saxophone, oboe, or flute, that's pitch. You make it sound that high when you play anything “over the break.” Since about half of the instrument's range lies over the break, you'll be playing up there a lot — but probably not until your second or third year. The E flat soprano clarinet plays that high pretty much all the time, but it is very rarely used and appears almost exclusively in orchestras. If you mean that you like the clarinet to sound sort of nasally or reedy like it is a saxophone no matter how high or low the note is, that's timbre (pronounced TAWM-burr). You can make a clarinet sound more nasally or reedy by using a softer reed, but beware: your teachers will all try to get you to stop, because that isn't “good characteristic tone” for a clarinet. It will also prevent you from developing the muscles required to play clarinet well. About the only place you can get away with using a too-soft reed consistently is in pep band, where the acoustics are terrible and everyone is playing loudly all the time. If you like the high notes, be patient and practice, and you'll get there. If you like the reedy/nasally sound, switch to saxophone.

I am no expert but the sound of the clarinet, which comes in at least two sizes, is different from the sound of the saxophone, which comes in at least 3 sizes. The pitch should not make either sound like the other.
